context: Along the mudflats of Garantia exist two types of annelids: earthworms and lugworms. Earthworms tend to emerge from the mud early in the morning when there is more moisture and nutrients. As a result, earthworms have access to more nutrients and thus reproduce far faster than the lugworm, which spends much of the day submerged in the mud. Nonetheless, the lugworm population far outnumbers that of the earthworm.
question: How does the fact that lugworms have specialized taste receivers, which allow them to access nutrients below ground far more easily than earthworms can, help least to resolve the apparent discrepancy noted above?
answer0: If the whooping crane hunts mainly during times that the earthworms are feeding at the surface, that would only decrease the population of the earthworms, but not less than what they would have from not feeding at the surface and not increase the lugworms population at all.
answer1: If lugworms are able to access nutrients below ground more easily then earthworms can, then it's possible for the lugworm to actually reproduce more than previously thought and increase their population.
answer2: The businessman states that sales is the most important part of any business and that every other department other than sales should be eliminated.
answer3: While this is true, it is again more of a common knowledge that businesses have multiple departments and not vital to the businessman's argument.

context: A clothing manufacturer reports that unsalable garments, those found to be defective by inspectors plus those returned by retailers, total 7 percent of the garments produced. Further, it reports that all of its unsalable garments are recycled as scrap, but the percentage of garments reported as recycled scrap is 9 percent.
question: Why does the fact that the total number of garments produced by the manufacturer has increased slightly over the past year not contribute to explaining the discrepancy between the reported percentages?
answer0: If the overall number of produced garments is up, the number of recycled garments would also likely be up.
answer1: If different methods are being used in regards to tracking recycled items, the number may not be as accurate since there could be different levels of accuracy between weighing and counting garments.
answer2: Garments with defects not being recycled would cause the number of recycled items to be lower rather than higher.
answer3: Defects being reported would not necessarily increase the number of recycled scrap since not all may be recycled and those being mislabeled as defective would not necessarily be recycled.

context: Half a dozen Q40 airliners have crashed in the past two years. The manufacturer has countered claims that the Q40' s design is faulty by pointing out that, in each of the accidents, investigations indicated pilot error as the cause.
question: Explain why the fact that one of the crashes occurred in very poor visibility when the pilot was attempting to land does not provide the strongest support for the manufacturer's position.
answer0: If the majority of the crashes were caused by such egregious pilot error, then it provides support for there being nothing wrong with the planes.
answer1: A crash at night could be pilot error, but it could also be a problem in the equipment the pilot relied on for poor night visibility.
answer2: If this was true, then pilot error shouldn't have caused a crash and that it was at least partially an issue with the plane.
answer3: Some of those other factors could have been due to poor design or manufacture.

context: People who object to the proposed hazardous waste storage site by appealing to extremely implausible scenarios in which the site fails to contain the waste safely are overlooking the significant risks associated with delays in moving the waste from its present unsafe location. If we wait to remove the waste until we find a site certain to contain it safely, the waste will remain in its current location for many years, since it is currently impossible to guarantee that any site can meet that criterion. Yet keeping the waste at the current location for that long clearly poses unacceptable risks.
question: Why does the fact that the statements above strongly support the waste being placed in the most secure location that can ever be found not necessarily follow?
answer0: The author wants the waste moved immediately, even if the ideal location hasn’t been found.
answer1: The threat in leaving the waste at the current location must be a greater danger than the danger posed by putting it in a new location.
answer2: One would have to do an assessment of the situation to see if urgency needs to be applied when moving the waste.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The habit many students on today' s campuses have of scribbling in their textbooks is inexcusable. It is harmful to books, aesthetically displeasing, and distracting to readers who buy the textbooks used.

answer0: It doesn't matter if many students don't scribble so long as there are still many students who do.

answer2: Even if books in public school libraries are abused more than textbooks that doesn't change that textbooks are abused.
answer3: Students have a purpose in buying the scribbled in textbooks and want to do so.

context: Secondary school students achieve broad mastery of the curriculum if they are taught with methods appropriate to their learning styles and they devote significant effort to their studies. context: Besides laying eggs in her own nest, any female wood duck will lay an egg in the nest of another female wood duck if she sees the other duck leaving her nest. Under natural nesting conditions, this parasitic behavior is relatively rare because the ducks' nests are well hidden. However, when people put up nesting boxes to help the ducks breed, they actually undercut the ducks' reproductive efforts. These nesting boxes become so crowded with extra eggs that few, if any, of the eggs in those boxes hatch.
question: What is the reason for why the statements do not strongly support the claim that the nesting boxes for wood ducks have less space for eggs than do natural nesting sites?
answer0: The passage does not say if wood ducks with female companions produce more eggs or not.
answer1: The sizes of the nesting boxes or natural nests are not mentioned in the passage.
answer2: The passage does not indicate if wood ducks prefer nests or nest boxes.
answer3: The passage indicates that because the nest boxes are obvious, that more eggs are laid in them causing them not to hatch.

context: Besides laying eggs in her own nest, any female wood duck will lay an egg in the nest of another female wood duck if she sees the other duck leaving her nest. Under natural nesting conditions, this parasitic behavior is relatively rare because the ducks' nests are well hidden. However, when people put up nesting boxes to help the ducks breed, they actually undercut the ducks' reproductive efforts. These nesting boxes become so crowded with extra eggs that few, if any, of the eggs in those boxes hatch.
question: What is the evidence that the statements above strongly support the claim that the nesting boxes would be more effective in helping wood ducks breed if they were less visible to other wood ducks than they currently are?
answer0: The passage does not say if wood ducks with female companions produce more eggs or not.
answer1: The passage does not indicate if wood ducks prefer nests or nest boxes.
answer2: The passage indicates that because the nest boxes are obvious, that more eggs are laid in them causing them not to hatch.
answer3: The sizes of the nesting boxes or natural nests are not mentioned in the passage.

context: Philosopher: Both the consequences and the motives of human actions have bearing on the moral worth of those actions. Nonetheless, to be a moral agent one must have free will, because one cannot be a moral agent without desiring to conform to a principle.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that the philosopher's argument does not depend on the assumption that nobody who acts without taking the consequences of the action into consideration is free?
answer0: Moral agency requiring conformation to a principle regarding its likely effects is stated explicitly in the argument, and is not an assumption made by it.
answer1: Acting thoughtlessly and amorally can still be done freely, as the assumption of the necessity of freedom made in the passage only concerns moral actions.
answer2: The argument concerns only one specific type of desire, not desires in general.
answer3: If moral actions require confirmation to a principle, if follows that if a desire for such confirmation requires free will then so will the moral actions that result from it.

context: Principle: If you sell an item that you know to be defective, telling the buyer that the item is sound, you thereby commit fraud. Application: Wilton sold a used bicycle to Harris, knowing very little about its condition. Wilton told Harris that the bicycle was in good working condition, but Harris soon learned that the brakes were defective. Wilton was ttherefore guilty of fraud.
question: What is the reason for why the application of the principle is not considered to be flawed for not establishing whether Wilton was given the opportunity to repair the brakes?
answer0: The principle does not take consider whether the buyer believed the seller's statements about the item's condition.
answer1: Wilton knew very little about the bicycle's condition and presumably didn't know that the brakes were defective, which is contrary to the premise of the principle.
answer2: There is no indication that the defect observed in the application is inconsistent with how "defective" is used in the statement of the principle.
answer3: The principle does not take consider whether the seller had an opportunity to address or repair the known defects.

context: Charlene: Environmental cleanup increasingly relies on microorganisms to metabolize pollutants. This has its limitations, though, since microbes become less active when a region' s temperature drops below normal. Olaf: I don' t think that' s right. Researchers studying oil spills in the Arctic and subtropical regions measured the carbon dioxide output of organisms that digest petroleum pollutants and found that Arctic and subtropical microbes ate oil at nearly the same rate.
question: What evidence is there that Olaf does not misinterpret Charlene's use of the term "cleanup"?
answer0: He is not calling into question what cleanup means as he speaks of oil spills and microbes eating the oil to help with the cleanup
answer1: He does not appear to misunderstand limitations as he is speaking about how he does not feel the microbes are limited by the drop in temperature
answer2: He seems to understand what active means as he speaks about the microbes eating the oil at nearly the same rate.
answer3: He appears to think this means whatever temperature he considers to be "normal" or "comfortable" or "average" rather than "normal" for a particular region.

context: According to some astronomers, Earth is struck by a meteorite large enough to cause an ice age on an average of once every 100 million years. The last such incident occurred nearly 100 million years ago, so we can expect that Earth will be struck by such a meteorite in the near future. This clearly warrants funding to determine whether there is a means to protect our planet from such meteorite strikes.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be flawed for presuming, without evidence, that some feasible means can be found to deter large meteorite strikes?
answer0: That the patrons prefer to not eat potatoes is not treated as a cause for them ordering the casserole or the brown rice.
answer1: The author clearly states they want to attempt to find whether or not there is a way to deter strikes, meaning they imply that it might not be possible.
answer2: The conclusion that their patrons prefer to not eat potatoes is not inconsistent with the premise that the other two vegetarian dishes are ordered more often.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.option: presumes, without providing justification, that some feasible means can be found to deter large meteorite strikes

question: Why is the reasoning in the argument subject to criticism for moving from evidence about the average frequency of an event to a specific prediction about when the next such event will occur?
answer0: Candidates should run for office if they can get funded but should not feel compelled to compromise their principles.
answer1: The author states that they occur on average every 100 million years, but then implies that one is imminent because it's been 100 million years since the last one, despite the fact that averages don't represent absolutes.
answer2: The author does not presume that it occurring 100 million years ago as opposed to the 100 million year average is not relevant, they do the opposite.
answer3: Voters should know that funding has to come from somewhere but should feel that they should know who is funding.

context: Leptin, a protein occurring naturally in the blood, appears to regulate how much fat the body carries by speeding up the metabolism and decreasing the appetite when the body has too much fat. Mice that do not naturally produce leptin have more fat than other mice, but lose fat rapidly when they are given leptin injections. Unfortunately, however, leptin cannot be used as a dietary supplement to control fat, since__.
question: What is the basis for not concluding that people with unusually low levels of leptin in their blood tend to have a high percentage of body fat logically completes the passage?
answer0: Leptin is stated to occur naturally in the blood.
answer1: The underlying issue causing low levels of leptin could also be causing other symptoms as well, such as increased body fat.
answer2: The mice who are producing their own leptin are not loosing weight until receiving the injected form.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Educator: Some experimental educational programs, based on the principle that children' s first education should take place at home, instruct parents in how to be their child' s "first teacher. " The school performance of the children in these programs is better than average. This shows that these programs are successful and should be expanded.
question: Explain why the fact that the cost of expanding the programs has not been precisely determined does not weaken the educator's argument.
answer0: This option cuts against the causal chain that's at the crux of the educator’s argument. If it's true that most of the parents participating in the program have prior experience as educators, then the program does not turn the parents into fake “teachers,” because they already are teachers.
answer1: The practical cost of the program expansion doesn't have any bearing on the validity of the argument.
answer2: This is not relevant to the conclusion, which is focused on the success of the program in enabling parents to teach their children.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: FilmPro sells millions of videocassettes directly to consumers at $25 apiece for a $10 profit on each. So far, one million illegally copied cassettes have been sold for $5 each. Illegal copying, ttherefore, has cost the company at least $10 million in potential profits.
main_question.question: Which of the following is an assumption that, if true, would allow the conclusion above to be properly drawn?
main_question.option: FilmPro never sells discontinued videocassettes at less than $25 apiece.

context: This boulder is volcanic in origin and yet the rest of the rock in this area is sedimentary. Since this area was covered by southward-moving glaciers during the last ice age, this boulder was probably deposited here, hundreds of miles from its geological birthplace, by a glacier.
question: Explain why the fact that most boulders that have been moved by glaciers have not been moved more than 100 miles does not seriously undermine the conclusion drawn in the argument.
answer0: A southern volcano being closer would not change the likelihood of a glacier moving the boulder to its new location.
answer1: This only states that most boulders have been moved less than a 100 miles by glaciers, which means it is still possible that the passage is correct.
answer2: The boulder could not have been carried by a south moving glacier if there are no volcanic locations for it to be picked up from to the north.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Two investigative journalists have raised the question whether the new blood pressure drug, Transerythropaxil, has sensitized patients to develop fish allergies. The study was published last month in a major newspaper, and has been picked up by media throughout the country. Lab data has long shown that Transerythropaxil reacts strongly with Eicosapentaenoic acid, found in abundance in fish oil, and this reaction can produce biological irritants. Despite strenuous objections from Transerythropaxil' s manufacturer, scientists working in federal labs have just published papers that provide conclusive evidence to the journalists' claim.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the first portion in boldface identifies the content of the conclusion of the argument and the second provides support for that conclusion?
answer0: the argument doesn't seek to blame society's problems on school failures, but rather the other way around
answer1: The first identifies what the two investigative journalists have concluded and the second shows the lab data that supports this conclusion.
answer2: the argument doesn't rely on presenting schooling as a social problem
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.question: In the argument given, the two portions in boldface play which of the following roles?
main_question.option: The first identifies the content of the conclusion of the argument; the second provides support for that conclusion.

context: Therapist: In a recent study, researchers measured how quickly 60 different psychological problems waned as a large, diverse sample of people underwent weekly behavioral therapy sessions. About 75 percent of the 60 problems consistently cleared up within 50 weeks of therapy. This shows that 50 weekly behavioral therapy sessions are all that most people need.
question: Why is the therapist's argument not logically flawed for not considering the possibility that some forms of therapy have never been proven to be effective as treatments for psychological problems?
answer0: The authenticity of the cynicism is irrelevant, and does not indicate whether it would or would not harm society.
answer1: the argument doesn't make a blanket statement about all forms of therapy, but instead makes a more general statement on how therapy should be approached for most people
answer2: since it is unknown what the 60 problems were, they could be incredibly niche ones and therefore the argument wouldn't be as strong
answer3: The author only argues for the absence of negative effects, not that the cynicism is valuable.

context: It is highly likely that Claudette is a classical pianist. Like most classical pianists, Claudette recognizes many of Clara Schumann' s works. The vast majority of people who are not classical pianists do not. In fact, many people who are not classical pianists have not even heard of Clara Schumann.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be invalid due to its presumption, without evidence, that classical pianists cannot also play other musical instruments?
answer0: People who have not heard of Clara Schumann are logically not capable of recognising work as belonging to her; such an assumption would justify itself.
answer1: No presumption is made about classical pianists' ability to play any instrument other than the piano.
answer2: If most of the people who recognise Clara Schumann's works are not classical pianists, then the assumption that Claudette is a classical pianists based on nothing other than her ability to recognise those works is greatly undermined.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Columnist: The amount of acidic pollutants released into the air has decreased throughout the world over the last several decades. We can expect, then, an overall decrease in the negative environmental effects of acid rain, which is caused by these acidic pollutants.
question: Why does the columnist's argument not become weaker even if it is assumed that some ecosystems have developed sophisticated mechanisms that reduce the negative effects of increased levels of acids in the environment?
answer0: If the soils of many ecosystems that have been exposed to acid rain have been exhausted of the minerals that help protect them from acid rain's harmful effects, it is likely there are still going to be negative effects seen and so not an overall decrease as is stated.
answer1: If the decrease in acidic pollutants is expected to end soon, we would not be able to expect an overall decrease in the negative environmental effects of acid rain.
answer2: If some ecosystems have developed sophisticated mechanisms that reduce the negative effects, it would likely aid in an overall decrease in the negative effects of acid rain.
answer3: If the effects of acid rain are cumulative, the damage will take quite a while to undo as it will increase before it decreases.

context: Environmentalist: The commissioner of the Fish and Game Authority would have the public believe that increases in the number of marine fish caught demonstrate that this resource is no longer endangered. This is a specious argument, as unsound as it would be to assert that the ever-increasing rate at which rain forests are being cut down demonstrates a lack of danger to that resource. The real cause of the increased fish-catch is a greater efficiency in using technologies that deplete resources.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the environmentalist's statements support the claim that the proportion of marine fish that are caught is as high as the proportion of rain forest trees that are cut down each year?
answer0: The passage uses the rainforest as an example for a theory, not a comparison to the fish.
answer1: The passage does not say if the fish are eaten or not.
answer2: The argument in the passage claims that the amount of fish caught does not indicate how many there actually are.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: Environmentalist: The commissioner of the Fish and Game Authority would have the public believe that increases in the number of marine fish caught demonstrate that this resource is no longer endangered. This is a specious argument, as unsound as it would be to assert that the ever-increasing rate at which rain forests are being cut down demonstrates a lack of danger to that resource. The real cause of the increased fish-catch is a greater efficiency in using technologies that deplete resources.
main_question.question: The environmentalist's statements, if true, best support which of the following as a conclusion?
main_question.option: The proportion of marine fish that are caught is as high as the proportion of rain forest trees that are cut down each year.

context: Philosopher: We should not disapprove of the unearthing of truths that we would rather not acknowledge or that, by their dissemination, might influence society in pernicious ways.
question: Why does the fact that a poem need not adhere too strictly to the truth and that art is exempt from such requirements not conform closely to the principle stated by the philosopher?
answer0: This is unlike the philosopher's principle because it is making exceptions fo certain circumstances.
answer1: Truth being unimportant to art is unlike the principle which is about the need to uncover truth.
answer2: How difficult it is for predators to spot the lugworms and earthworms does not necessarily have a significant affect on how often they reproduce and their population.

context: The level of sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere is slightly higher than it was ten years ago. This increase is troubling because ten years ago the Interior Ministry imposed new, stricter regulations on emissions from coal-burning power plants. If these regulations had been followed, then the level of sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere would have decreased.
question: Why is it not valid to infer that, if current regulations on emissions from coal-burning power plants are not followed from now on, then the level of sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere will continue to increase based on the statements above?
answer0: The assumption is looking for a cause of past levels not ongoing ones.
answer1: The assumption is that if regulations had been strictly followed than there would be a decrease in the level of sulfur dioxide over the past ten years thus an increase would suggest the regulations have not be strictly adhered to.
answer2: The validity of the health advice provided by journalists is not questioned by either party.
answer3: No effort is made to address how to conquer the anxiety that may result from avoiding health risks.

context: Carol: The best choice for investment is real estate because the payout is huge. Even though the market can be a little unpredictable, it' s the quickest way to turn a sizable profit. Kenny: Real estate is way too risky and people get huge sums of money tied up into one house that sometimes they can' t sell or the value depreciates precipitously. It' s much wiser to invest in dependable things like utilities or bonds.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that Kenny is not willing to take risks only if the potential payout is huge based on the text above?
answer0: Since Carol is willing to participate in a volatile market like real estate and Kenny is not it stands to reason she is more willing to take risks overall.
answer1: Whether the payout is huge or not does not play into Kenny's estimation of real estate risk.
answer2: The passage's author mentions that Kenny would invest in safer assets like bonds, however stocks may not be any safer than real estate in his view given his propensity for investment vehicles.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Since empathy is essential for people to be willing to follow moral codes that sometimes require them to ignore their own welfare to help others, civilized society could not exist without empathy.

context: It is clear that humans during the Upper Paleolithic period used lamps for light in caves. Though lamps can be dated to the entire Upper Paleolithic, the distribution of known lamps from the period is skewed, with the greatest number being associated with the late Upper Paleolithic period, when the Magdalenian culture was dominant.
question: Why does the fact that artifacts from early in the Upper Paleolithic period are harder to identify than those that originated later in the period not contribute to an explanation of the skewed distribution of lamps?
answer0: More types of lamps being produced implies that a higher quantity was produced as well since some of each kind would have to be made for more types to exist.
answer1: Fire pits are not a practical way to light paths or enclosed areas and would not affect how often lamps would be needed.
answer2: Artifacts being harder to identify would more likely result in less of them being identified than more.
answer3: A culture being more efficient at making lamps does not necessarily imply that more were made overall.

context: Advertising tends to have a greater influence on consumer preferences regarding brands of yogurt than it does on consumer preferences regarding brands of milk. Yet, since the LargeCo supermarket chain began advertising its store-brand products, sales of its storebrand milk increased more than sales of its store-brand yogurt.
question: Explain why the fact that shoppers at LargeCo tend to purchase the chain's own brand of dairy products more frequently than other brands of dairy products does not help to resolve the apparent discrepancy described above?
answer0: It's possible the typical shopper going to buy yogurt also has no intention of buying milk, but then neither should be affected by advertising of the product.
answer1: Both the store-brand milk and the store-brand yogurt are the chain's own brand, so sales of both should have increased similarly.
answer2: The store-brand of milk is not necessarily less expensive than other non-store brands.
answer3: If stores nationwide have experienced a decrease in yogurt sales, it's possible the advertising increasing the amount of yogurt sales did not do so enough to cover the downturn.

context: Community activist: If Morganville wants to keep its central shopping district healthy, it should prevent the opening of a huge SaveAll discount department store on the outskirts of Morganville. Records from other small towns show that whenever SaveAll has opened a store outside the central shopping district of a small town, within five years the town has experienced the bankruptcies of more than a quarter of the stores in the shopping district.
question: How would knowing the proportion of stores in towns with healthy central shopping districts that suffer bankruptcy during a typical five-year period help to evaluate the community activist's reasoning?
answer0: Whether there has been any successful campaign or not is not strong evidence that SaveAll may pose a threat to the town's smaller stores.
answer1: If a large proportion of the stores have closed down, it will bolster the activist's reasoning. If only a small proportion of the stores closed down, it will hurt his/her reasoning.
answer2: Whether Morganville residents do all their shopping in Morganville or elsewhere does not help answer the question whether SaveAll hurts its smaller businesses.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The obsession of economists with consumption as a measure of economic well-being has prevented us from understanding the true nature of economic well-being. We get very little satisfaction out of the fact that our clothing wears out, our automobiles depreciate, and the gasoline in our tanks burns up and must be replaced.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that the author's argument does not rely on the idea that modern products are designed for early obsolescence?
answer0: The statement never discusses consumption and never suggests that valid measures cannot be devised for consumption (or for economic wellbeing).
answer1: The passage does not suggest that consumption is not necessary to satisfaction.
answer2: This isn't the main point; the products cited just explained that aspects of economic well-being are not captured by measuring consumption.
answer3:
The conclusion of the argument is that too much of  a focus on consumption prevents a true understanding of economic wellbeing, meaning that
economic wellbeing cannot be defined solely by consumption.

context: Pharmacist: A large study of people aged 65 -- 81 and suffering from insomnia showed that most of insomnia' s symptoms are substantially alleviated by ingesting melatonin, a hormone produced by the pineal gland, which plays a role in the regulation of the body' s biological clock. Thus, the recent claims made by manufacturers of melatonin supplements that the pineal gland produces less melatonin as it ages are evidently correct.
question: Why is the pharmacist's argument not considered to be invalid due to inferring from the effect of an action that the action is intended to produce that effect?
answer0: The statement does not use two different meanings or rely on two different meanings.
answer1: We're provided with a very specific age group, and thus we can't make it a general statement.
answer2: The argument uses an effect to identify a cause.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Salesperson: If your vacuuming needs are limited to cleaning small areas of uncarpeted floors, an inexpensive handheld vacuum cleaner is likely to be sufficient. After all, most are easy to use and will likely satisfy all your vacuuming needs on wood and tile floors.
question: Why does the conclusion of the salesperson's argument not be strongly supported even if it is assumed that if your household cleaning needs include cleaning small areas of uncarpeted floors, it is likely that you will need a vacuum cleaner?
answer0: The salesman refers only to a case of uncarpeted floors in his argument, and so the sufficiency for cleaning carpeted floors is not relevant.
answer1: If carpet, wood and tile are the only possible types of flooring, then the salesman's argument that the product he describes is effective on wood and tile can logically be extended to apply to all floors which do not have carpeting.
answer2: A relationship between cost and versatility does not undermine the salesman's argument that a cheap vacuum cleaner can still be effective in the very specific situation he describes.
answer3: Needing a vacuum cleaner per se in such circumstances does not support or contradict the salesman's assertions regarding the type of vacuum cleaner which will suffice.

context: Zoologist: In the Lake Champlain area, as the North American snowshoe hare population grows, so do the populations of its predators. As predator numbers increase, the hares seek food in more heavily forested areas, which contain less food, and so the hare population declines. Predator populations thus decline, the hare population starts to increase, and the cycle begins again. Yet these facts alone cannot explain why populations of snowshoe hares everywhere behave simultaneously in this cyclical way. Since the hare population cycle is well correlated with the regular cycle of sunspot activity, that activity is probably a causal factor as well.
question: Why does the fact that brighter light during sunspot activity subtly but significantly improves the ability of predators to detect and capture hares not support the zoologist's reasoning?
answer0: this wouldn't necessarily invalidate the recommendation if it were true, as there could be more research centers than farms that would benefit
answer1: the existence of even better alternatives wouldn't necessarily mean the biomedical device approach wouldn't still be a good alternative
answer2: If local weather patterns that can affect species' population changes can occur both in the presence of sunspot activity and in its absence, this would call into question the conclusion that the sunspot activity is the cause
answer3: If the brighter light from sunspot activity affects predators ability to detect and capture hares, this would indicate that sunspot activity is a causal factor

context: Journalist: Well-known businessman Arnold Bergeron has long been popular in the state, and he has often talked about running for governor, but he has never run. However, we have just learned that Bergeron has fulfilled the financial disclosure requirement for candidacy by submitting a detailed list of his current financial holdings to the election commission. So, it is very likely that Bergeron will be a candidate for governor this year.
question: What is the rationale for why answering the question of whether submitting a list of holdings is the only way to fulfill the election commission's financial disclosure requirements would not be useful in evaluating the journalist's argument?
answer0: Whether or not there are other requirements wouldn't effect the likelihood of the disclosure requirement making him likely to win the candidacy.
answer1: Checking if this had led to similar results in the past would be the best way of determining the value of the argument.
answer2: The source by itself wouldn't be a very effective way of evaluating the argument .
answer3: Whether they increased or decreased wouldn't have any effect on the author's argument

context: Last winter was mild enough to allow most bird species to forage naturally, which explains why the proportion of birds visiting feeders was much lower than usual. The mild winter also allowed many species to stay in their summer range all winter without migrating south, thereby limiting the usual attrition accompanying migration. Hence, last year' s mild winter is responsible for this year' s larger-than-usual bird population.
question: Why does the fact that birds sometimes visit feeders even when they are able to find sufficient food for survival by foraging naturally not strengthen the reasoning in the argument?
answer0: The anomalous behaviour of an unspecified number of birds does not strengthen any argument based on the behaviour of birds as a whole, as it's relative significance cannot be determined.
answer1: Without knowing whether "unusual weather patterns" includes an exceptionally mile winter, the relevance of this information to the case described cannot be evaluated.
answer2: Whether or not managers give higher rankings to workers who have the same interests as them outside of work is not an effect of the ranking system itself being unfair.
answer3: Even if companies require their managers to give unique rankings, it is not always necessary for the way these rankings are implemented to be unfair.

context: Last winter was mild enough to allow most bird species to forage naturally, which explains why the proportion of birds visiting feeders was much lower than usual. The mild winter also allowed many species to stay in their summer range all winter without migrating south, thereby limiting the usual attrition accompanying migration. Hence, last year' s mild winter is responsible for this year' s larger-than-usual bird population.
question: Explain why the fact that birds that remain in their summer range all winter often exhaust that range's food supply before spring does not strengthen the reasoning in the argument.
answer0: If non-migrating birds exhausted their food supply, we would actually expect to see an increase in visits to feeders, rather than what was actually observed.
answer1: If extreme wind and precipitation is an effect of the difference in elevation from the highest mountain ranges, then the highest mountain ranges would be more likely to contain those erosive forces and cause them to be more prevalent the more difference in elevation.
answer2: Vulnerability to predators would provide a valid reason for birds to have avoided visiting feeders, and could explain the reduced frequency of visits even if birds were numerous due to the mild conditions, as those conditions would also yielded an increased natural food supply for them.
answer3: The process by which the differently elevated mountain ranges are formed should not affect how wind and precipitation wear down all mountain ranges.

context: Aaron: A prominent judge, criticizing "famous lawyers who come before courts ill-prepared to argue their cases, " recently said, "This sort of cavalier attitude offends the court and can do nothing but harm to the client' s cause. " I find the judge' s remarks irresponsible. Belinda: I find it natural and an admirable display of candor. Letting people know of the damage their negligence causes is responsible behavior.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that it is not reasonable to expect that ill-prepared lawyers would offend the court in which they appear?
answer0: Neither Aaron or Belinda believe having ill-prepared lawyers appear in court is in the best interest of their clients.
answer1: Aaron believes the judge is irresponsible for pointing out the incompetence of the lawyer in court, while Belinda believes that the judge was admirable for not allow the incompetence to slide.
answer2: Neither Aaron or Belinda disagree that incompetent lawyers are undesirable in court.
answer3: The issue that both Aaron and Belinda are concerned with is whether the lawyers are prepared, not whether they are famous.

context: Recent trends in the clothing industry have suggested that more clothing is being produced more quickly and cheaply than in the past; styles can go from the runway to stores in as little as three weeks. While most experts have focused on minimizing the time this process takes, True Clothing has in fact made efforts to take longer to produce its clothing.
question: How does the fact that some items of clothing can be worn in different ways to create different styles, depending on the individual consumers not help to explain the strategy of True Clothing referred to above?
answer0: The passage does not say how large the True Clothing brand is.
answer1: Putting more time and resources into designing a quality product would explain why it takes longer for True Clothing to put out new designs.
answer2: The number of ways an item can be worn has no bearing on how quickly it can be designed or manufactured.
answer3: The age of the person meant to wear the clothes shouldn't change how fast the clothes can be brought to market.

context: Ms. Smith: I am upset that my son' s entire class lost two days of recess because some of the children were throwing raisins in the cafeteria. He was not throwing raisins, and it was clear to everyone just who the culprits were. Principal: I' m sorry you' re upset, Ms. Smith, but your son' s situation is like being caught in a traffic jam caused by an accident. People who aren' t involved in the accident nevertheless have to suffer by sitting there in the middle of it.
question: Why is the principal's response to Ms. Smith's complaint vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it does not acknowledge the fact that a traffic jam following an accident is unavoidable while the mass punishment was avoidable?
answer0: The principal is not stating that one event is better or worse than the other, they are merely making an analogy about how sometimes, innocent people who are not at fault for an event must suffer because of it.
answer1: The principal does not make any generalization about the children, they only state that they are unfortunately victims due to other people's actions.
answer2: Losing recess is a punishment voluntarily doled out by the school, whereas having to suffer through the traffic jam caused by an accident is an unavoidable part of the event itself, not a punishment imposed after the fact.
answer3: The principal does not claim that Ms. Smith's son is guilty, they only state that innocent people unfortunately suffer just as they do in a traffic jam.

context: In Berinia, the age at which people could begin to drink alcohol legally used to be 18. In 1990, in an attempt to reduce alcohol consumption and thereby to reduce alcohol-related traffic deaths among Berinians under 21, the legal drinking age was raised to 21. Alcohol-related traffic deaths among people under 21 have decreased significantly since 1990. Nevertheless, surveys show that people in that age-group drink just as much alcohol as they did before 1990.
question: Why does the fact that alcohol-related traffic deaths among people over 21 have increased slightly since 1990 not help to resolve the apparent discrepancy regarding Berinia?
answer0: The focus of the author is that of the role of crayfish to the dragonfly larvae.  What other predators there are to the larvae are not known.
answer1: Alcohol consumption for the population as a whole doesn't explain how traffic death for those under 21 decreased.
answer2: Traffic deaths among people over 21 has no bearing on traffic deaths among people under 21.
answer3: The author discusses that the dragonfly larvae are what the crayfish eat.  The assumption could be that the dragonflies leave the water once matured.

context: Most people invest in the stock market without doing any research of their own. Some of these people rely solely on their broker' s advice, whereas some others make decisions based merely on hunches. Other people do some research of their own, but just as often rely only on their broker or on hunches. Only a few always do their own research before investing. Nonetheless, a majority of investors in the stock market make a profit.
question: Why is it not necessary that most people who rely solely on their broker rather than on hunches make a profit in the stock market in order for the argument to be valid?
answer0: Most investors make a profit but only a small number of investors do their own research, so there must be some profitable investors who do not do any research of their own.
answer1: The passage states that most investors make a profit, but it does not indicate that any of these profitable investors are people who do investment research on their own while just as often relying on their broker or on hunches.
answer2: The passage states that most investors make a profit, but it does not indicate that this is true for the subset of investors who do not do any research of their own.

context: Commentator: Many social critics claim that contemporary journalists' cynical tendency to look for selfish motives behind the seemingly altruistic actions of powerful people undermines our society' s well-being by convincing people that success is invariably associated with greed and mendacity. But the critics' claim is absurd. The cynicism of contemporary journalists cannot be a contributing factor to the undermining of our society' s well-being, for journalists have always been cynics. Today' s journalists are, if anything, more restrained than their predecessors.
question: Why is the commentator's argument not considered to be flawed for overlooking the possibility that the work of contemporary journalists reflects a cynicism that is not really genuine?
answer0: since it is unknown what the 60 problems were, they could be incredibly niche ones and therefore the argument wouldn't be as strong
answer1: the argument doesn't make a blanket statement about all forms of therapy, but instead makes a more general statement on how therapy should be approached for most people
answer2: The author only argues for the absence of negative effects, not that the cynicism is valuable.
answer3: The authenticity of the cynicism is irrelevant, and does not indicate whether it would or would not harm society.

context: Hollywood restaurant is replacing some of its standard tables with tall tables and stools. The restaurant already fills every available seat during its operating hours, and the change in seating arrangements will not result in an increase in the restaurant' s seating capacity. Nonetheless, the restaurant' s management expects revenue to increase as a result of the seating change without any concurrent change in menu, prices or operating hours.
question: Why does the fact that the standard tables being replaced by tall tables would otherwise have to be replaced with new standard tables at a greater expense not provide the reason for the expectation?
answer0: As the restaurant is already at seating capacity, even if fewer diners avoid the restaurant they would still only be able to serve a similar amount of diners.
answer1: Pollution levels themselves and not the effect of pollution is the issue.
answer2: Tall tables would not necessarily be less expensive than the standard tables.
answer3: It is possible the leveling-off trend will not continue, but the argument is made about what would happen if it did.

context: Environmentalist: The complex ecosystem of the North American prairie has largely been destroyed to produce cattle feed. But the prairie ecosystem once supported 30 to 70 million bison, whereas North American agriculture now supports about 50 million cattle. Since bison yield as much meat as cattle, and the natural prairie required neither pesticides, machinery, nor government subsidies, returning as much land as possible to an uncultivated state could restore biodiversity without a major decrease in meat production.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the environmentalist's main conclusion is that if earlier North American agricultural techniques were reintroduced, meat production would decrease only slightly?
answer0: The environmentalist argues for greatly increasing North American bison populations with the reintroduction of prairies, not just for preserving the remaining North American bison.
answer1: The environmentalist is arguing for returning land to prairies, not for North American agricultural techniques.
answer2: The environmentalist claims that in the past the prairie supported as many bison as there are cattle, so bison could be used for meat instead of cattle if the prairie was restored.
answer3: The environmentalist shows that bison could be used as meat but does not state that this would be more cost effective than raising domesticated animals.

context: Quasars -- celestial objects so far away that their light takes at least 500 million years to reach Earth -- have been seen since 1963. For anything that far away to appear from Earth the way quasars do, it would have to burn steadily at a rate that produces more light than 90 billion suns would produce. But nothing that burns at a rate that produces that much light could exist for more than about 100 million years.
question: Why is it not necessary to accept that instruments in use before 1963 were not sensitive enough to permit quasars to be seen on the basis of the statements given?
answer0: The argument is not that nothing a certain distance from the earth has existed for more than  million years but rather that something cannot sustain a burn for the number of years needed for the light to reach earth.
answer1: The argument is not whether a technology could allow for something to be seen but rather that it if it burned at a rate necessary to be seen that it would not last long enough to reach earth regardless of the technology available.
answer2: Whether a quasar exists now does not indicate how and when it existed before.
answer3: When light may have first reached the earth does not affect whether or not something burned at a rate high enough to be visible.

context: Several companies that make herbal teas containing ginseng assert in their marketing that ginseng counteracts the effects of stress. As a result, many people buy these products hoping to improve their health. Yet no definitive scientific study links ginseng with the relief of stress. Thus, these marketing campaigns make false claims.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered flawed for concluding that a claim is false merely on the grounds that it has not been shown to be true?
answer0: While the ginseng has not been definitely shown to relieve stress, that doesn't mean that it's not possible that it does, so it is incorrect to definitively claim they are making false claims.
answer1: The author does not reject the claim because of the source, they reject it because of a lack of evidence.
answer2: Whether or not people enjoy drinking the tea does not change the author's claim that the marketers are making false claims about how the ginseng in the tea relieves stress.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Consumer advocate: There is ample evidence that the model of car one drives greatly affects the chances that one' s car will be stolen. The model of car stolen most often in our country last year, for example, was also the model stolen most often in the preceding year.
question: Why is the consumer advocate's reasoning not considered to be flawed for assuming, without evidence, that someone considering whether or not to steal a particular car considers only what model the car is?
answer0: It stands to reason that the most commonly driven car in a country will also be the most available to steal.
answer1: The resale value of a car is only partially relevant, as not all cars are stolen for their monetary value.
answer2: The consumer is not arguing that thieves look to steal a particular car, only that the particular car is stolen most often multiple years in a row.
answer3: The age of a car is not relevant to the argument.

main_question.option: presumes, without providing justification, that someone considering whether or not to steal a particular car considers only what model the car is

context: Codex Berinensis, a Florentine copy of an ancient Roman medical treatise, is undated but contains clues to when it was produced. Its first 80 pages are by a single copyist, but the remaining 20 pages are by three different copyists, which indicates some significant disruption. Since a letter in handwriting identified as that of the fourth copyist mentions a plague that killed many people in Florence in 1148, Codex Berinensis was probably produced in that year.
question: Why does the fact that according to the account by the fourth copyist, the plague went on for 10 months not strongly support the hypothesis that Codex Berinensis was produced in 1148?
answer0: If the plague lasted for almost a year, then the letter merely proves that the fourth copyist was alive at some point after late 1848.
answer1: The lack of evidence as to when three of the four contributors to the copy were alive cannot strengthen any hypothesis as to when they made their contributions to it.
answer2: The length of time required to copy a single page is irrelevant, as we have no information as to how many pages the latter three copyists contributed.
answer3: If only one plague outbreak took place at around that time this strengthens the argument by removing the possibility of the fourth copyist having referred to a plague other than the 1848 one.

context: Many successful graphic designers began their careers after years of formal training, although a significant number learned their trade more informally on the job. But no designer ever became successful who ignored the wishes of a client.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that all graphic designers who are unsuccessful must have ignored the wishes of a client in order for the statement to be true?
answer0: If the buses in Springfield run more frequently and on longer routes, less routes would be needed
answer1: We are told that no designer that ever became successful ignored the wishes of a client.  We know there are successful designers, so this statement must be true.
answer2: If the average number of cars is higher in Springfield than in Rorchester, it is likely they drive more to work which would explain why the demand is lower in Springfield
answer3: We cannot assume that all designers who are unsuccessful have ignored the wishes of a client because there are many other reasons a graphic designer could prove to be unsuccessful.

context: Some airlines allegedly reduce fares on certain routes to a level at which they lose money, in order to drive competitors off those routes. However, this method of eliminating competition cannot be profitable in the long run. Once an airline successfully implements this method, any attempt to recoup the earlier losses by charging high fares on that route for an extended period would only provide competitors with a better opportunity to undercut the airline' s fares.
question: How does the fact that airline executives generally believe that a company that once underpriced its fares to drive away competitors is very likely to do so again if new competitors emerge weaken the argument?
answer0: If airline executives operate under the belief that a company that once underpriced its fairs to drive away competitors will likely do so again, they would be less likely to try and regain or acquire the routes that said company gained by these practices and so the company would not likely face competition on those routes going forward.
answer1: The number of passengers on the reduced rate routes increasing for the company who reduced the rates does not mean they would not switch to another company that reduced rates similarly in the future.
answer2: Whether or not most airlines would shift resources to other routes rather than reduce the size of their operations following the decision to stop serving particular routes would not determine whether or not said companies would fight to regain those routes if the competitor who drove them away decided to raise their fares.
answer3: If the legality of the companies actions were called into question, it would be even more likely that the company would lose the routes it had gained through these practices.

context: Doctor: Recent pharmaceutical advances will lead the way in weight loss. Prior to these advancements, obesity-related deaths outnumbered all other causes of death by a wide margin. The new drugs will curb appetite and increase metabolism. Thanks to these advancements, obesity will dramatically decline in the near future.
question: Why does the fact that participants in several studies reported significant appetite reductions not strengthen the doctor's argument?

context: The Asian elephant walks with at least two, and sometimes three, feet on the ground at all times. Even though it can accelerate, it does so merely by taking quicker and longer steps. So the Asian elephant does not actually run.
question: Why does the conclusion drawn above follow logically if it is assumed that to run, an animal must have all of its feet off the ground at once?
answer0: How usual or unusual it is for four-legged animals to use a certain number of legs while walking isn't relevant to anything the passage.
answer1: Nothing in the passage suggests anything about the speed at which an Asian elephant walks or that other animals run.
answer2: The passage claims the Asian elephant can accelerate, but cannot run, so even if it were true that running requires acceleration, it wouldn't logically follow from the passage.

context: Loggerhead turtles live and breed in distinct groups, of which some are in the Pacific Ocean and some are in the Atlantic. New evidence suggests that juvenile Pacific loggerheads that feed near the Baja peninsula hatch in Japanese waters 10, 000 kilometers away. Ninety-five percent of the DNA samples taken from the Baja turtles match those taken from turtles at the Japanese nesting sites.
question: Why does the fact that the distance between nesting sites and feeding sites of Atlantic loggerhead turtles is less than 5,000 kilometers not weaken the reasoning?
answer0: A high number of turtles from two separate areas very far apart sharing DNA suggests that turtles are travelling between the two areas or are interacting in some way to be related genetically.
answer1: How long turtles have been raised in captivity has no bearing on how they behave in nature.
answer2: Turtles declining in one area while not in another does not indicate that the turtles are leaving one area to go to the other as a variety of reasons could cause turtle numbers in an area to decrease such as disease, predators, etc.
answer3: Sites turtles using being  5000 km away does not explain how turtles 10000 km away from each other would mate.

context: The effects of technology on language and the effects of language on culture as a whole are profound and complex. The telegraph, the telephone, and the television have all changed the way people speak to one another. The best current example of such a change is the advent of electronic mail, which has effected a widespread loosening of language usage rules. This loosening has, in turn, made relationships between people more casual than ever before.
question: How does the evidence provided illustrate the proposition that changes in communication media can cause interpersonal relationships to change?
answer0: The statements do indicate a loosening of language rules, but make no judgment as to whether this actually improves communication.
answer1: The statements suggest that increased technological sophistication is in fact the cause of changing levels of linguistic sophistication, not the reverse.
answer2: The statements clearly indicate that the advent of electronic mail has caused communication in interpersonal relationships has become more casual.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Archaeologist: Researchers excavating a burial site in Cyprus found a feline skeleton lying near a human skeleton. Both skeletons were in the same sediment at the same depth and equally well-preserved, suggesting that the feline and human were buried together about 9, 500 years ago. This shows that felines were domesticated around the time farming began, when they would have been useful in protecting stores of grain from mice.
question: How does the fact that in Cyprus there are many burial sites dating from around 9, 500 years ago in which the remains of wild animals appear to have been buried alongside human remains weaken the archaeologist's argument?
answer0: The argument does not rely on any premises or assumptions related to the presence or absence of stores of grain near the burial site.
answer1: Whether or not felines hunted mice doesn't change whether the felines were domesticated or not, and the absence of paintings showing felines hunting mice doesn't mean that they did not hunt mice.
answer2: The argument assumes that an animal buried alongside a human must be a domesticated animal, but this assumption is false if there are burial sites where wild animals were buried alongside humans from the same time period and location.
answer3: The argument assumes co-burial is evidence of domestication, and whether or not farmers had a effective way to protect grain from mice before the domestication of felines has no bearing on the validity of this assumption.

context: This year a flood devastated a small river town. Hollyville, also a river town, responded with an outpouring of aid in which a majority of its residents participated, a proportion that far surpassed that of a few years ago when Hollyville sent aid to victims of a highly publicized earthquake. This year' s circumstances were a reversal of last year' s, when Hollyville itself was the scene of a deadly tornado and so the recipient rather than the supplier of emergency aid.
question: Explain why the situation described does not closely conform to the generalization that people are more likely to aid people they know than they are to aid strangers.
answer0: There is nothing in the passage indicating the people of Jollyville knew the people they helped before or the people that are helping them now.
answer1: Government relief programs are not mentioned at all by the passage
answer2: The support offered by Hollyville increased after they themselves needed assistance.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: In any field, experience is required for a proficient person to become an expert. Through experience, a proficient person gradually develops a repertory of model situations that allows an immediate, intuitive response to each new situation. This is the hallmark of expertise, and for this reason computerized "expert systems" cannot be as good as human experts. Although computers have the ability to store millions of bits of information, the knowledge of human experts, who benefit from the experience of thousands of situations, is not stored within their brains in the form of rules and facts.

context: A person' s dietary consumption of cholesterol and fat is one of the most important factors determining the level of cholesterol in the person' s blood (serum cholesterol). Serum cholesterol levels rise proportionally to increased cholesterol and fat consumption until that consumption reaches a threshold, but once consumption of these substances exceeds that threshold, serum cholesterol levels rise only gradually, even with dramatic increases in consumption. The threshold is one fourth the consumption level of cholesterol and fat in today' s average North American diet.
question: What is the evidence that supports the claim that people who consume half as much cholesterol and fat as in the average North American diet will not necessarily have half the average serum cholesterol level?
answer0: The availability of the millipedes to capuchin would clearly effect their ability to rub them into their fur, and so greater availability at a specific time could plausibly explain a greater likelihood of rubbing behavior at that same time, undermining the alternative explanation for it offered by the passage.
answer1: The idea that the most important factors for a person's serum cholesterol levels are cholesterol and fat does not exclude other factors from also being able to impact those levels.
answer2: Other locations in which the millipede are found are not relevant to the motivations of capuchins in one specific location.
answer3: As the average diet is already four times higher than the consumption level, even reducing it by half to twice the consumption level would exceed the threshold, and thus both would only rise gradually rather than proportionally resulting in higher than half the average serum cholesterol.

context: Lines can be parallel in a Euclidean system of geometry. But the non-Euclidean system of geometry that has the most empirical verification is regarded by several prominent physicists as correctly describing the universe we inhabit. If these physicists are right, in our universe there are no parallel lines.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument does not depend on the assumption that only physicists who are not prominent doubt the view that the universe is correctly described by the non-Euclidean system of geometry that has the most empirical verification?
answer0: The physicists who doubt the view are not important to the assumption.
answer1: The passage doesn't state that non-Euclidean geometry does not have any parallel lines but it must be assumed to reach the conclusion that there are no parallel lines in our universe if those prominent physicists are correct.
answer2: The passage only states several physicists regard the view as correct , but it does not state most or does it need to be assumed because only the view of the several prominent physicists is being offered.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: A recent study confirms that nutritious breakfasts make workers more productive. For one month, workers at Plant A received free nutritious breakfasts every day before work, while workers in Plant B did not. The productivity of Plant A' s workers increased, while that of Plant B' s workers did not.
question: Why does the fact that workers from Plant A took fewer vacation days per capita during the month than did workers from Plant B not strengthen the argument?
answer0: The status of workers in the month before the study is not relevant to the present month's results.
answer1: If workers at Plant B and Plant A both ate breakfasts that were not nutritious to begin with, and only Plant A began eating nutritious, then that directly supports the argument about higher productivity being linked to the nutritious breakfasts.
answer2: When workers take fewer vacation days, they produce more at work because they are working more hours.
answer3: Whether or not workers in Plant B were more productive is irrelevant, as the only results that would weaken or strengthen the argument are changes that occurred during the study as a result of getting a free breakfast.

context: Until about 400 million years ago, fishes -- the first true swimmers -- were jawless. Their feeding methods were limited to either sucking in surface plankton or sucking in food particles from bottom mud. With the development of biting jaws, however, the life of fishes changed dramatically, since jaws allowed them actively to pursue prey, to seize it in their jaws, and to manipulate it between their teeth. The jawed fishes then developed along two main lines: one retained cartilage for its skeletons, for example, sharks and rays; the other adopted bone as its principal skeletal material. From the latter group evolved the most abundant and diverse of all of today' s vertebrate groups, the "teleosts, "some 21, 000 species, which vary from barracudas to sea horses.
question: What evidence supports the claim that the jawless fishes did not prey upon other fish?
answer0: We are told that the jawless fish was limited to either sucking in surface plankton or sucking in food particles from bottom mud, so we can be certain that jawless fish did not prey upon other fish.
answer1: While we know that fish are the primary prey of some jawed fishes, we cannot be certain based upon the information in the passage that this applies to all jawed fishes.
answer2: the argument is a supporting one, not a main conclusion
answer3: the argument is an example of a concession strategy commonly used in debate

main_question.option: The jawless fishes did not prey upon other fish.

main_question.context: Until about 400 million years ago, fishes -- the first true swimmers -- were jawless. Their feeding methods were limited to either sucking in surface plankton or sucking in food particles from bottom mud. With the development of biting jaws, however, the life of fishes changed dramatically, since jaws allowed them actively to pursue prey, to seize it in their jaws, and to manipulate it between their teeth. The jawed fishes then developed along two main lines: one retained cartilage for its skeletons, for example, sharks and rays; the other adopted bone as its principal skeletal material. From the latter group evolved the most abundant and diverse of all of today' s vertebrate groups, the "teleosts, "some 21, 000 species, which vary from barracudas to sea horses.
main_question.question: If all of the statements in the passage are true, which one of the following must also be true?
main_question.option: Teleosts do not feed upon particles found in bottom mud.

context: A researcher studying corporate executives found that they tend to have "take charge" personalities, with the predominant traits of assertiveness, decisiveness, and self-confidence. The researcher concluded that people who are more "take charge" than the average person are more likely to become corporate executives.
question: Explain why the fact that many people who aspire to become executives exhibit different management styles in their current jobs does not significantly weaken the researcher's conclusion.
answer0: The researcher's conclusion has nothing to do with whether or not the executives were good at family activities.
answer1: The researcher did mention people with a "take charge" personality were more likely to become an executive but it was not completely guaranteed. Some people with such a personality may very well not get that role.
answer2: If people had to develop an assertive personality during the job, they most certainly were not as assertive before which conflicts with the researcher's conclusion.
answer3: Saying different management styles were exhibited is very vague and partially compatible with the researcher's conclusion if the style is assertive.

context: Commentator: In many countries the influence of fringe movements is increasing. The great centrifugal engine of modern culture turns faster and faster, spinning off fashions, ideologies, religions, artistic movements, economic theories, cults, and dogmas in fabulous profusion. Hence, modern culture threatens the national identities that now exist in the world.
question: Explain why the fact that the rate of cultural change in most countries will soon change drastically does not weaken the commentator's argument?
answer0: If the idea that compositing a large number of subcultures creates a more stable national identity, then modern culture would be stabilizing current national identities instead.
answer1: If the rate of cultural change will soon change drastically, it only supports the fact that more modern culture threatens the existing national identity.
answer2: The preference for pluralistic or monolithic national cultures do not change whether or not those monolithic national cultures are being threatened.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: A survey has shown that public perceptions of comparative risks differ radically from the assessments of risk-management experts. For example, living near a nuclear power plant was judged a much greater risk by the survey respondents than it was by the experts. On the other hand, exposure to X-rays was judged a significantly lower risk by the survey respondents than it was by the experts. Psychologists have found that people tend to be more worried about risks they consider involuntary than about risks they consider voluntary. Thus the survey results were probably caused by the respondents' tendency to consider involuntary risks to be greater than they actually are.
question: What is the reasoning for the argument not requiring the assumption that the survey's respondents did not include people living near nuclear power plants?
answer0: This could also be true based upon the passage, but we are not told whether the food or the water is the heavier or lighter content of the cans.
answer1: In order for the respondents to view the power plant as a greater risk, they would have to believe that many had no choice in living near a power plant, because the hypothesis is that people view involuntary risk as more dangerous.
answer2: This information is not contained in the passage as we are not told how much the water or the fruits and vegetables weigh in relation to one another inside of the cans.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Any driver involved in an accident leading to personal injury or property damage exceeding $500 is legally required to report the accident to the department of motor vehicles, unless the driver is incapable of doing so. context: Planetary bodies differ from one another in their composition, but most of those in the Solar System have solid surfaces. Unless the core of such a planetary body generates enough heat to cause volcanic action, the surface of the body will not be renewed for millions of years. Any planetary body with a solid surface whose surface is not renewed for millions of years becomes heavily pockmarked by meteorite craters, just like the Earth' s Moon. Some old planetary bodies in the Solar System, such as Europa, a very cold moon belonging to Jupiter, have solid icy surfaces with very few meteorite craters.
question: What evidence from the passage supports the conclusion that some very cold planetary bodies have cores that generate enough heat to cause volcanic action?
answer0: Only Europa is discussed and the claims made do not indicate that the other moons are heavily pockmarked or similar to Europa.
answer1: The assumption is that coal burning power plants are one cause not the only cause.
answer2: Any planetary body with a solid surface whose surface is not renewed for millions of years becomes heavily pockmarked by meteorite craters and the renewal happens by volcanic action from enough heat produced within the core. If Europa has solid icy surfaces with very few meteorite craters, it would seem as though Europa has a core that generates enough heat to cause volcanic action.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Goronian lawmaker: Goronia' s Cheese Importation Board, the agency responsible for inspecting all wholesale shipments of cheese entering Goronia from abroad and rejecting shipments that fail to meet specified standards, rejects about one percent of the cheese that it inspects. Since the health consequences and associated costs of not rejecting that one percent would be negligible, whereas the cost of maintaining the agency is not, the agency' s cost clearly outweighs the benefits it provides.
question: Why is it not relevant to know the answer to how the cheese rejected by the Cheese Importation Board is disposed of in order to evaluate the lawmaker's argument?
answer0: If the possibility of having their cheese rejected discourages many cheese exporters from shipping substandard cheese to Goronia, it is possible the amount of cheese actually sent does not help cover the costs of operation
answer1: If it reduced its operating costs by eliminating inefficiencies, this would make it possible to argue that the benefits could outweigh the costs
answer2: If something is produced in Goronia, it is unlikely it is being imported into Goronia a sit is already there
answer3: The disposal of the rejected cheese is not of import and would most likely be a negligible cost that would not contribute to the high cost of maintenance by very much

context: In 1988, a significant percentage of seals in the Baltic Sea died from viral diseases; off the coast of Scotland, however, the death rate due to viral diseases was approximately half what it was for the Baltic seals. The Baltic seals had significantly higher levels of pollutants in their blood than did the Scottish seals. Since pollutants are known to impair marine mammals' ability to fight off viral infection, it is likely that the higher death rate among the Baltic seals was due to the higher levels of pollutants in their blood.

answer0: The passage doesn't claim that the pollutant each animal faced were the same or had the same effects.
answer1: The fact the other mammals in the area also died from viral disease would indicate that there was a problem in the area.
answer2: The passage does not provide the age or health of the dead Baltic seals, so this option could be supportive or not.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: People who need to reduce their intake of fat and to consume fewer calories often turn to fat substitutes, especially those with zero calories such as N5. But studies indicate that N5 is of no use to such people. context: It takes 365. 25 days for the Earth to make one complete revolution around the Sun. Long-standing convention makes a year 365 days long, with an extra day added every fourth year, and the year is divided into 52 seven-day weeks. But since 52 times 7 is only 364, anniversaries do not fall on the same day of the week each year. Many scheduling problems could be avoided if the last day of each year and an additional day every fourth year belonged to no week, so that January 1 would be a Sunday every year.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the proposal, once put into effect, would be likely to result in continued scheduling conflicts for employed people whose strict religious observances require that they refrain from working every seventh day?
answer0: We are not told whether or not customers are happy or unhappy with the speed of service at Hatfield Airport, only staff members feel they cannot serve their customers efficiently.
answer1: Religious observances have their own schedule and thus changing the calendar could cause conflict for those individuals who must also follow a calendar work week.
answer2: The date of a birthday would still fall of the same date regardless of the day of the week.
answer3: We are not given information in terms of which airlines at Hatfield Airport are widely used or not widely used in comparison to AirJet.
