context: Clark: Our local community theater often produces plays by critically acclaimed playwrights. In fact, the production director says that critical acclaim is one of the main factors considered in the selection of plays to perform. So, since my neighbor Michaela' s new play will be performed by the theater this season, she must be a critically acclaimed playwright.
question: What is the reason for not criticizing Clark's argument on the grounds that it uses as evidence a source that there is reason to believe is unreliable?
answer0: The conclusion is flawed because of the author of the statement is certain without any reason. Based on the evidence provided, the author could fairly conclude that there is a chance that M's play is critically acclaimed, but the author is overstating their case by being certain of something that is only possible rather than certain.
answer1: This is not true as we have no reason to believe the evidence is unreliable.
answer2: The argument doesn't imply any form of causality.
answer3: Critical acclaim is just one of my factors and it is not sufficient or necessary for the selection of plays.

context: It is said that people should accept themselves as they are instead of being dissatisfied with their own abilities. But this is clearly a bad principle if the goal is a society whose citizens are genuinely happy, for no one can be genuinely happy if he or she is not pursuing personal excellence and is unwilling to undergo personal change of any kind.
question: What is the reasoning for why the argument does not require the assumption that people are justified in feeling content with themselves when they have achieved some degree of personal excellence?
answer0: Whether or not people should be content with themselves after achieving personal excellence is not relevant to the author's argument about what achieving personal excellence requires.
answer1: The author doesn't claim that those willing to change will probably find genuine happiness, only that people unwilling to change certainly won't.
answer2: The author refers to people accepting themselves as they are instead of being dissatisfied with their own abilities being bad because those people will not pursue excellence, so they believe the former is a requirement for the latter.
answer3: Nothing about something being painful is mentioned by the author, dissatisfaction is not equivalent to pain.

context: Creating a database of all the plant species in the scientific record has proved to be no easy task. For centuries, botanists have been collecting and naming plants without realizing that many were in fact already named. And by using DNA analysis, botanists have shown that varieties of plants long thought to belong to the same species actually belong to different species.
question: Why is it not justified to reject the claim that duplicates and omissions in the scientific record also occur in fields other than botany on the basis of the statements above?
answer0: Seeing as the passage is saying it is no easy feat and due to the issues addressed and how much work to correct said problems, it is very likely most of the duplicates and omissions among plant names in the scientific record have yet to be cleared up.
answer1: If there were no methods for determining whether or not distinct plant species have been given distinct names, botanists would not be able to see that some plants previously thought to be the same species are not nor would they know there are those being named after having bene previously.
answer2: The amount of duplicates and omissions in other fields is not relevant to the passage, though it is very likely the same could be true for other fields.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Working residents of Springfield live, on average, farther from their workplaces than do working residents of Rorchester. question: Why does the fact that three-fourths of the Springfield workforce is employed at the same factory outside the city limits not contribute to a resolution of the apparent discrepancy described above?
answer0: If Springfield has a larger population that Rorchester, it would be expected even more that the demand for public transportation would be higher in Springfield.
answer1: the argument only deals with what would increase chances at election, and not on how politicians vote
answer2: the argument only deals with tariffs, and has nothing to say more generally about what politicians should support
answer3: If 3/4 of the Springfield workforce is employed at the same factory outside of the city limits, the residents could carpool to save money rather than use public transportation

context: Businessman: Sales are the most important part of any business. Marketing and communications are never as effective as a strong sales team. Persuasive salesmen can sell as many units of an inferior product as average salesmen with better quality products. Our company should eliminate every department except the sales team.
question: What is the basis for not assuming that the businessman's argument depends on the assumption that businesses often have other departments besides marketing, communications, and sales?
answer0: If lugworms are able to access nutrients below ground more easily then earthworms can, then it's possible for the lugworm to actually reproduce more than previously thought and increase their population.
answer1: If the whooping crane hunts mainly during times that the earthworms are feeding at the surface, that would only decrease the population of the earthworms, but not less than what they would have from not feeding at the surface and not increase the lugworms population at all.
answer2: The businessman states that sales is the most important part of any business and that every other department other than sales should be eliminated.
answer3: While this is true, it is again more of a common knowledge that businesses have multiple departments and not vital to the businessman's argument.

context: Pundit: Our city made a mistake when it sold a private company the rights to assess and collect parking fees. The private company raised parking fees and so has been able to reap profits far greater than what it paid for the rights to assess and collect the fees. If the city had not sold the rights, then that money would have gone to the city.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the pundit's argument requires the assumption that the city could have raised parking fees had it not sold the rights?
answer0: the argument was not trying to establish a general rule
answer1: the argument is not about efficiency, but rather who gets the money
answer2: by ending the argument with the money would've been going to the city otherwise, this is exactly what the argument is assuming.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Conscientiousness is high on most firms' list of traits they want in employees. Yet a recent study found that laid-off conscientious individuals are less likely to find jobs within five months than are their peers who shirked their workplace responsibilities.
question: Why does the claim that people who shirk their workplace responsibilities are less likely to keep the jobs they have, so there are more of them looking for jobs not help to resolve the apparent paradox?
answer0: If a person has performed well and conscientiously and was still laid off, this would probably lead to resentment and they may not speak very well of their previous employer or be as optimistic in their following interviews.
answer1: If someone is conscientious, they are more likely to engage in saving behavior as well and so would be able to also conscientiously look for suitable employment leading to them being hired less quickly than their workplace responsibility shirking counterparts
answer2: A conscientious person is more concerned with doing a good and thorough job and so would be more concerned with finding one where they would be able to do so and so would likely be hired less quickly
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Emissions from automobiles that burn gasoline and automobiles that burn diesel fuel are threatening the quality of life on our planet, contaminating both urban air and global atmosphere. Ttherefore, the only effective way to reduce such emissions is to replace the conventional diesel fuel and gasoline used in automobiles with cleaner-burning fuels, such as methanol, that create fewer emissions.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the argument depends on the assumption that reducing the use of automobiles would not be a more effective means to reduce automobile emissions than the use of methanol?
answer0: Since the call to action references the use of alternative fuels it logically must follow that this is a requirement for fewer emissions and must be better than reducing automobiles in general.
answer1: A direct correlation between urban air pollution and the quality of the global atmosphere has no bearing on whether or not the pollution can be reduced through the use of gas alternatives.
answer2: Whether or not automobile owners select methanol over gasoline has no bearing on whether the fuel alternatives can reduce emissions.
answer3: Automobile emissions are a threat but do not constitute the most serious threat

context: In comparison to the standard typewriter keyboard, the EFCO keyboard, which places the most-used keys nearest the typist's strongest fingers, allows faster typing and results in less fatigue. Ttherefore, replacement of standard keyboards with the EFCO keyboard will result in an immediate reduction of typing costs.
question: Explain why the fact that the number of businesses and government agencies that use EFCO keyboards is increasing each year does not weaken the conclusion drawn above.
answer0: An increase in the use of EFCO keyboards does not tell us anything about the impact on the organizations or people using those keyboards, or how it might affect costs.
answer1: Someone who has never used a keyboard can learn to use an EFCO or a standard keyboard in about the same amount of time, so there is no additional training time required but we do not know if or how it might affect costs in the long run.
answer2: The more practice an employee has with a standard keyboard, the more time and expense it will take to retrain them on an EFCO keyboard, so the immediate impact on an organization making the switch will be an increase in typing costs.
answer3: The fact that it is easier to transition to an EFCO keyboard from a standard one, rather than a standard keyboard to an EFCO, does not tell us how quickly that transition occurs or how it might affect costs

context: Lenore: It is naive to think that historical explanations can be objective. In evaluating evidence, historians are always influenced by their national, political, and class loyalties. Victor: Still, the very fact that cases of biased thinking have been detected and sources of bias identified shows that there are people who can maintain objectivity.
question: Why does Victor's response fail to rebut Lenore's argument if it overlooks the possibility that those who detect and identify bias are themselves biased in some way?
answer0: If there were sources of bias other than national, political, and class loyalty, this would only further the case that no historian could have been objective.
answer1: If those who detect and identify bias are also biased themselves then there is still no evidence of people who maintain objectivity.
answer2: Providing examples for cases where bias has been detected and identified still does not imply that those involved in those cases were objective.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Whenever an artist endowed with both a high level of artistic skill and a high degree of creativity combines these two abilities in the process of creating an artwork, the resulting product is a great work of art. Moreover, no work of art can be great unless both of these elements are combined in its execution. Thus, great works of art are necessarily rare.
question: What is the reasoning for why the argument does not require the assumption that an artist endowed with a high degree of creativity and a high level of artistic skill will necessarily produce great works of art?
answer0: This assumption is not required because according to the passage, a high degree of creativity is also needed for a great work of art.
answer1: The passage states that these traits only mean that a work of art can be great , but not necessarily will be.
answer2: According to the statement, artistic skill and creativity is necessary for great works of art, but it is not knowable how many will be produced.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: On the whole, scientists do their most creative work before age forty, a tendency that has been taken to show that aging carries with it a loss of creative capacity. An alternative explanation is that by age forty most scientists have worked in their field for fifteen or more years and that by then they have exhausted the opportunity for creative work in that field. Supporting this explanation is the finding that __.
question: What is the reason for the average age of recipients of scientific research grants not being significantly greater than forty not logically completing the passage?
answer0: There's nothing to suggest a correlation between a scientist's own expectations for their work and the reality of their opportunities for creativity.
answer1: Whether older scientists find more satisfaction in other pursuits or not doesn't support an explanation about how many opportunities they have for creative work.
answer2: Receiving a research grant is not necessarily an indicator that the scientist has been doing more creative work; in fact age could be an advantage due to having more tenure in the scientific community.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Studies of the political orientations of 1, 055 college students revealed that the plurality of students in an eastern, big-city, private university was liberal, whereas in a state-supported, southern college, the plurality was conservative. Orientations were independent of the student' s region of origin, and the trends were much more pronounced in seniors than in beginning students.
question: What evidence from the observations stated above supports the hypothesis that the political orientations of college seniors depend significantly on experiences they have had while in college?
answer0: The study found the same phenomenon among both liberal and conservative students, so not all were becoming more conservative.
answer1: The study showed the same conclusions regardless of where the student was raised, so it is likely not the household they were raised in that was the deciding factor.
answer2: If the political concentration of the students is not based on their native upbringing and it is more pronounced after four years in college, that means that they were influenced by the political climate of the school.
answer3: If the political orientation was just based on state vs. private schools, there wouldn't have been a significant change in the political stance of the students near the end of their college life.

context: Historian: The standard "QWERTY" configuration of the keys on typewriters and computer keyboards was originally designed to be awkward and limit typing speed. This was because early typewriters would jam frequently if adjacent keys were struck in quick succession. Experiments have shown that keyboard configurations more efficient than QWERTY can double typing speed while tremendously reducing typing effort. However, the expense and inconvenience of switching to a new keyboard configuration prevent any configuration other than QWERTY from attaining widespread use.
question: What evidence does the historian provide to strongly support the claim that if the keyboard had been designed for computers, then it would not have been designed to limit typing speed?
answer0: A different device wouldn't require a design characteristic like this.
answer1: Benefits haven't been discussed at all.
answer2: We don't have any evidence that some keyboards today are more likely to jam.
answer3: We can't say that "most" people typed faster with non-QWERTY keyboards.

main_question.question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the historian's statements?
main_question.option: If the keyboard had been designed for computers, then it would not have been designed to limit typing speed.

context: In the United States proven oil reserves -- the amount of oil considered extractable from known fields -- are at the same level as they were ten years ago. Yet over this same period no new oil fields of any consequence have been discovered, and the annual consumption of domestically produced oil has increased.
question: Why does the fact that oil exploration in the United States has slowed due to increased concern over the environmental impact of such exploration not reconcile the discrepancy described above?
answer0: Only the use of domestic oil is said to have increased which is a separate issue than use of imported oil.
answer1: The annual consumption of oil is said to have increased rather than decreased.
answer2: Oil exploration slowing does not explain how reserves remain at the same level despite increased use.
answer3: If more oil has become extractable, it is logical to assume that even with increased use, increased availability would neutralize the effects of increased use in regards to reserve amounts.

main_question.option: Oil exploration in the United States has slowed due to increased concern over the environmental impact of such exploration.

context: When interviewing job candidates, personnel managers not only evaluate a candidate' s work experience and educational background but also inquire about hobbies. Personnel managers try to justify these inquiries by noting that the enthusiasm someone shows for a hobby may well carry over to enthusiasm for a job. But such enthusiasm may also indicate that the candidate is less concerned with work than with play. Ttherefore personnel managers should not inquire about a candidate' s hobbies.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the argument is not flawed for overlooking the possibility that inquiries about a hobby may put candidates at ease, eliciting more honest responses about important questions?
answer0: If certain hobbies indicate good organizational skills, then the personnel manager would need to determine what kind of hobby they have to see if the candidate has good organizational skills.
answer1: If asking about a hobby elicits more honest responses about more important questions, then this may be valued more by the personnel manager than enthusiasm for their job.
answer2: If candidates who have no hobbies pretend to have one in an interview, then asking about hobbies will not be reflective of whether the candidate actually has a hobby which would translate into enthusiasm.
answer3: If involvement in hobbies could indicate longer commitments, then the personnel manager should want to ask about hobbies to evaluate their enthusiasm.

But such enthusiasm may also indicate that the candidate is less concerned with work than with play. Ttherefore personnel managers should not inquire about a candidate' s hobbies.
main_question.question: The argument is flawed because it overlooks each of the following possibilities EXCEPT:
main_question.option: Inquiries about a hobby may put candidates at ease, eliciting more honest responses about important questions.

answer0: If asking about a hobby elicits more honest responses about more important questions, then this may be valued more by the personnel manager than enthusiasm for their job.
answer1: If certain hobbies indicate good organizational skills, then the personnel manager would need to determine what kind of hobby they have to see if the candidate has good organizational skills.
answer2: If candidates who have no hobbies pretend to have one in an interview, then asking about hobbies will not be reflective of whether the candidate actually has a hobby which would translate into enthusiasm.
answer3: If involvement in hobbies could indicate longer commitments, then the personnel manager should want to ask about hobbies to evaluate their enthusiasm.

main_question.context: When interviewing job candidates, personnel managers not only evaluate a candidate' s work experience and educational background but also inquire about hobbies. Personnel managers try to justify these inquiries by noting that the enthusiasm someone shows for a hobby may well carry over to enthusiasm for a job. But such enthusiasm may also indicate that the candidate is less concerned with work than with play. Ttherefore personnel managers should not inquire about a candidate' s hobbies.
main_question.question: The argument is flawed because it overlooks each of the following possibilities EXCEPT:
main_question.option: Having certain kinds of hobbies may indicate that a candidate has good organizational skills.
